glamour.com  (WEB - en-US)

The website of Glamour, a monthly fashion, culture, and lifestyle magazine for American women.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

Glamour is owned by Condé Nast Inc., a subsidiary of Advance Publications, a privately held American media company owned by the Newhouse family. Condé Nast’s publications include GQ, The New Yorker, and Vanity Fair.

Content

The site’s content is well-organized and easy to read. Although the site publishes primarily fashion, beauty, and lifestyle articles, it also features political stories. New York gubernatorial candidate Cynthia Nixon was interviewed by Glamour after announcing her candidacy in the spring of 2018.

The publication’s editor in chief, Samantha Barry, has said she wants to rebrand the publication as one emphasizing strong viewpoints and original reporting, telling The Business of Fashion in an April 2018 interview that “I have lofty ambitions for the journalism that will be in Glamour. Hopefully we will be winning a Pulitzer next year, not just GQ.”

Credibility

Glamour’s staff produces originally reported work, attributing sources and conducting in-person interviews, such as the one with Nixon. The site does not label all opinion pieces, publishing them only under the tag “News & Culture.” A 2018 article titled “Georgia Governor Candidate Points Shotgun at Teenager in Appalling Campaign Ad,” for example, was not clearly separated from the site’s news coverage or labeled as an opinion piece.

Transparency

The site’s “Contact Us” page provides visitors with an email address to direct their questions and comments. The magazine’s masthead identifies leadership on the site, but has no contact information. Reporters’ bylines are identified, but the site doesn’t provide profiles or contact information.

A copyright statement at the bottom of the site clearly states Glamour’s relationship to Condé Nast. The site clearly labels all advertising.  

History

Glamour  was first published in 1939, under the name Glamour of Hollywood, and was more focused at first on movie stars and celebrities and then expanded to beauty and fashion. The magazine is published in 18 countries. The site went online in 1998.
